key_title: Key to the species of Chenopodium

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Chenopodiaceae

source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Chenopodiaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Walsh, N.G. (1996). Chenopodiaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Annual, prostrate to erect herbs; leaves mostly toothed or lobed (entire in C. vulvaria and C. desertorum)
Perennial shrubs; leaves entire (sometimes hastate)
Tepals glabrous
Tepals mealy, at least when young
Tepals free
Tepals united for at least half their length
Seed smooth or minutely pitted; fruiting tepals enclosing seed
Seed prominently pitted in approximate spiralled or concentric lines; fruiting tepals widely opened, with prominent midrib; weedy herb of Suggan Buggan area
Plants with an unpleasant odour (resembling rotting fish) when crushed
Plants without an unpleasant odour
Tepals shortly united at base only
Tepals united to near apex
Stems ridged and prominently streaked; leaves usually toothed to some extent, the largest exceeding 2 cm in length; weedy, erect annuals
Stems terete, evenly covered when young with white vesicular hairs; leaves entire, to c. 1 cm long; native, prostrate to weakly erect perennials or annuals
Seed obtuse around equator, shining, smooth; pericarp easily detached from seed
Seed acutely keeled around equator, dull, finely pitted; pericarp persistent
Shrubs not or hardly spinescent, to 1 m high; leaves distinctly mealy, at least on lower surface, to c. 1.5 cm long
Spinescent shrub to c. 2 m high; leaves sparsely mealy, oblong to spathulate, to 3 cm long
Leaves triangular, hastate or semicircular; fruit succulent, yellow to red; inflorescence a terminal drooping spike
Leaves mostly ovoid to obovoid; fruit not or hardly succulent; inflorescence erect or axillary
